title: Joseph Anderson Panton
text:
Joseph Anderson Panton (2 June 1831 – 25 October 1913) was a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a>-born <a href="Australia">Australia</a>n magistrate and goldfields commissioner.
Panton was born in <a href="Knockiemil">Knockiemil</a>, <a href="Aberdeenshire">Aberdeenshire</a>, <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>, the son of John Panton (of the Hudson's Bay Company service) and his wife Alexina McKay, "née" Anderson. Joseph Panton was educated at the <a href="Scottish%20Naval%20and%20Military%20Academy">Scottish Naval and Military Academy</a>, developing an interest in drawing. He later studied geology amongst other subjects at the <a href="University%20of%20Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a>, but did not finish a degree.
Panton's uncle, Colonel Joseph Anderson, suggested that he migrate to Australia; Panton arrived in <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> aboard the <a href="Thomas%20Arbuthnot%20%28ship%29">"Thomas Arbuthnot"</a> in March 1851. He then went to the <a href="Port%20Phillip%20District">Port Phillip District</a>. After farming briefly at <a href="Mangalore%2C%20Victoria">Mangalore</a>, Panton tried for gold without luck at <a href="Shire%20of%20Mount%20Alexander">Mount Alexander</a>. Then Panton applied for a position as an officer in the gold escort and was appointed assistant commissioner in 1852 at Kangaroo Gully near <a href="Bendigo%2C%20Victoria">Bendigo, Victoria</a>. A year later he was senior assistant commissioner at Bendigo and then senior commissioner in 1854.
Panton investigated resentment against the Chinese gold-diggers and recommended a Chinese protectorate; this was adopted by <a href="Charles%20Hotham">Governor Charles Hotham</a> in 1855. Panton had helped to organize the <a href="List%20of%20world%27s%20fairs">Melbourne Exhibition in 1854</a> and was a commissioner for the <a href="Melbourne%20International%20Exhibition%20%281880%29">Melbourne International Exhibition (1880)</a>.
In 1858, Panton went to Scotland and then to <a href="Paris">Paris</a> to study art with a friend of his, <a href="Hubert%20de%20Castella">Hubert de Castella</a>. On Panton's return to Australia, he was appointed warden and magistrate at the Jamieson-Wood's Point and next at the Anderson's Creek goldfields. Panton then became magistrate at Heidelberg, where he also mapped the <a href="Yarra%20Valley">Yarra Valley</a>, naming Panton Hill. Panton's Gap where the road to Ben Cairn and Donna Buang branches from the Don Road near <a href="Healesville%2C%20Victoria">Healesville, Victoria</a> derives its name from a small house he had there. He also named <a href="Mount%20Donna%20Buang">Mount Donna Buang</a> which he first called Mount Acland but renamed it after learning the Aboriginal name. From Heidelberg, Panton was transferred to <a href="Geelong">Geelong</a> and moved to Melbourne as senior magistrate from 1874 to 1907.
Panton was active in the <a href="Victorian%20Artists%20Association">Victorian Artists Association</a> and the Victorian Academy of Art which developed into the <a href="Victorian%20Artists%20Society">Victorian Artists Society</a>. A fellow of the <a href="Royal%20Geographical%20Society">Royal Geographical Society</a> (London), Panton was also vice-president of the <a href="Royal%20Geographical%20Society%20of%20Australasia">Royal Geographical Society of Australasia</a>, Victorian Branch.
In 1895 Panton declined the honour of knighthood but was appointed Companion of the <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">Order of St Michael and St George</a> (CMG). Predeceased by his wife, he died at <a href="St.%20Kilda%2C%20Victoria">St. Kilda, Victoria</a> on 25 October 1913 and was survived by two daughters, one of whom, Alice, was a well-known portrait painter.
In 1882, the Victorian government botanist, <a href="Ferdinand%20von%20Mueller">Ferdinand von Mueller</a> named a newly described plant from Western Australia, "<a href="Eremophila%20pantonii">Eremophila pantonii</a>" in his honour.
